{{TranscriptBlock

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:26.719
    | text      = So I'm going to read you some of the salient points from this 60 page report that the Oxford Energy Institute put out.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:34.719
    | text      = Love their dictionary by the way.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:36.719
    | text      = Quote the night of the 5th of January and early hours of the 6th of January were possibly the key moments in the crisis as far as deliveries to Europe were concerned.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:44.719
    | text      = On the 5th a televised and rather obviously staged conversation between Prime Minister Putin and Gazprom CEO Miller rehearsed all the Russian grievances against Ukraine
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:43:54.719
    | text      = which culminated in Putin agreeing with Miller's proposal to reduce the gas flows and instructing him to inform Gazprom's European partners about the reasons for the action.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:03.719
    | text      = At this point on the 7th of January the second and more serious stage of the dispute began.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:09.719
    | text      = Gas was cut off completely to countries in southeastern Europe which are 100% dependent on Russian imports and partially to other countries for 13 days.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:19.719
    | text      = Russian and Ukrainian sides blamed each other and neither displayed great urgency about moving towards agreement.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:24.719
    | text      = It is important to underline the unprecedented nature of this situation.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:27.719
    | text      = Supplies to Europe had never been halted since the gas transit system was built in Soviet times.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:33.719
    | text      = The two sides finally negotiated two new contracts covering supply and transit which were signed on the 19th of January.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:39.719
    | text      = Gas flows to Europe restarted on the morning of the 20th and two days later were returning to normal levels.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:45.719
    | text      = So that's sort of just a description of what happened and then they get to their conclusions.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:50.719
    | text      = A crisis in Russia-Ukraine bilateral gas relations is not in itself a surprise.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:55.719
    | text      = Many including ourselves had seen it coming as long ago as the summer of 2008.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:44:59.719
    | text      = The surprise indeed the shock was that both sides allowed the dispute to escalate from disagreements about debts, prices and transit tariffs to the point where supplies to Europe were completely shut off
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:09.719
    | text      = and then allowed the situation to continue for two weeks in the middle of winter with serious adverse humanitarian consequences for especially southeast European countries.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:18.719
    | text      = We do not believe the often cited desire of the Russian government to use energy as an economic or political weapon against European countries played any part in this crisis.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:28.719
    | text      = Russia's relationship with Europe and the gas sphere is and will remain one of mutual dependence.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:33.719
    | text      = While Europe depends heavily on Russian gas supplies, Russia which here means both Gazprom and the Russian state relies heavily on revenues generated from European sales.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:44.719
    | text      = By contrast, the critical Russian decision to cut back deliveries on the 5th of January, Russia did it, was an unnecessarily risky and commercially irrational action at this stage of the dispute.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:45:57.719
    | text      = That decision may have reflected Prime Minister Putin's anger and frustration and been aimed at punishing Ukraine for its repeated threats to disrupt transit.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:06.719
    | text      = Forty years of Russia's reputation as a secure gas supplier and Ukraine's reputation as a secure transit country have been damaged, probably irreparably.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:15.719
    | text      = The Russian government almost certainly personalized to Prime Minister Putin, which took the decisions which eventually led on the 7th of January to the complete interruption of European supplies through the Ukrainian transit network,
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:27.719
    | text      = should have recognized these consequences and had the option of stepping back.
}}

{{TranscriptBlock
    | name      = Unknown Speaker
    | timestamp = 00:46:31.719
    | text      = So if I understand correctly, what they said was Putin threw a tantrum.

{{TranscriptBlock

    | text      = But also, Russia made the decision to shut off the gas, which Alex is putting the other direction on. He's saying that Ukraine shut it off.
